document.docTitle: Description of a new species of the genus Woznessenskia from Xizang, China (Orthoptera: Gryllacrididae)

subSection.paragraph:
The gryllacridid genus
Woznessenskia Gorochov, 2002
comprises 13 extant species from Asia, with 8 species reported from China and 5 species reported from Vietnam . A new species from Xizang , China ,
Woznessenskia lianhua
sp. nov.
, is reported in this paper.

Key words:
Woznessenskia
,
new species
, Medog ,
Xizang
,
China
, taxonomy

Gorochov (2002) proposed the genus
Woznessenskia
with description of three new species,
W . finitima Gorochov, 2002
( type species),
W . arcuate Gorochov, 2002
, and
W . deminuta Gorochov, 2002
from Vietnam , and reclassified
Borneogryllacris curvicauda Bey-Bienko, 1962
into the genus
Woznessenskia
. Guo & Shi (2011) reported three new species,
W . bimacula Guo & Shi, 2011
,
W . brevisa Guo & Shi, 2011
, and
W . arcoida Guo & Shi, 2011
from China . Additional species
W . ampliata Ingrisch, 2018
and
W . bavi Ingrisch, 2018
, were delineated by Ingrisch (2018) from Vietnam . Subsequently,
Shi et al . (2022)
identified four new species,
W . incurva , Shi, Zhu & Wang, 2022
,
W . procera , Shi, Zhu & Wang, 2022
,
W . truncata , Shi, Zhu & Wang, 2022
and
W . combina , Shi, Zhu & Wang, 2022
from China . As of now, the genus
Woznessenskia
includes thirteen species, with eight species reported from China and five species reported from Vietnam ( Table 1 ).

In this paper,
W . lianhua
sp. nov.
, a new species from Xizang , China is described. It is different from other species in its spotless pronotum and needle-like apex of the processes on male tenth abdominal tergite. The type specimen is deposited in the Museum of Biology, East China Normal University (ECNU).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Type localities of
Woznessenskia species.

subSection.paragraph: Living individuals were photographed by Canon G7X3.Abdominal features were photographed just after individuals killed by ethanol. Fore wing venation was photographed with Nikon D3100 equipped with TAMRON SP 90mm F/2.8 Di MACRO 1:1 VC USD. All other diagnostic characteristics were photographed by a Leica M125 stereo microscope, and micro-graphs were captured with SC2000 digital CMOS camera and arranged using a combination of Adobe Photoshop 2023 v 24.3.0 and Adobe Illustrator 2022. Measurements conform to the standards of Guo & Shi (2011) . The measurements were conducted in accordance with the conventions outlined below: body length—distance from apex of fastigium verticis to posterior margin of ninth abdominal tergite in the midline; pronotum length—distance from anterior to posterior margins of pronotum; fore wings length—distance from base of fore wings to apex; postfemur length—distance from base of postfemur to apex of genicular lobe of postfemur; ovipositor—distance from basal margin of subgenital plate to apex of ovipositor. Nomenclature of fore wings veins follows Ingrisch (2018) as in Table 2 .

heading.emphasis:
Woznessenskia lianhua
sp. nov. Zhang, Hu & He NJa沃DZẽ

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Pronotum without darkish spots, apex of processes on male tenth abdominal tergite needle-like, while those of other species serrated.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype :
♂ Beibeng Township , Medog County , Xizang , China ( 29°15.85′ N 95°13.39′ E , Alt.
805 m
),
27 July 2023
, collected by Zhu-Qing He (ECNU-4948).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Paratype :
1♀ , same data as for holotype (ECNU-5053)
.
Pronotum. Anterior margin slightly protruding; posterior margin rounded ( Fig. 1A–C ).

Legs. Procoxa with a spine along anterior margin; profemur and mesofemur without spine; protibiae and mesotibiae with four pairs of lengthy ventral spines and one pair of short ventral spurs; mesotibiae with a subapical spur on inner dorsal side; postfemora with ten inner spines and eight outer spines on ventral margin ( Fig. 1I ); posttibiae with six inner spines and seven outer spines on dorsal margin, ventral margins with one pre-apical spine each, three apical spurs on both sides.

Wings. Fore wings obviously surpassing abdomen, close to three times as long as postfemora; R with two branches, both forked near tip; M bifurcated into MA and MP, MA without further branch and free; MP extending downwards for a distance, and intersecting with CuA1 to form MP+CuA1, which extending forwards for a distance and then bifurcated again for two parallel veins; CuA bifurcated into CuA1 and CuA2, CuA1 connecting with MP, CuA2 without further branch and free; CuP free throughout ( Fig. 3A, C ). Hind wings slightly longer than fore wings.

Coloration. Body orange-yellow ( Fig. 4A–B ); compound eyes blackish brown; ocelli orange-yellow; genae beneath eyes with a thin black stripe separately; fastigium verticis blackish brown; pronotum spotless, with thin black stripe along entire margin and the central portion orange-yellow; spines and spurs on all femora and tibiae blackish-brown with basal parts orange-yellow; fore wings semi-transparent, veins dark brown; hind wing semi-transparent, veins dark brown; abdominal tergites black.
Measurements (mm). Body: ♂ 22.1, ♀ 22.2; pronotum: ♂ 4.0, ♀ 5.1; fore wings: ♂ 36.0, ♀ 37.0; postfemur: ♂ 13.5, ♀ 14.8; ovipositor: 11.3.
Etymology. The name “lianhua ”, means “lotus flowers” in Chinese and is an alternative name for Medog. Chinese name: NJa沃DZẽ

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Photographs of male
Woznessenskia lianhua
sp. nov.
(holotype, ECNU-4948). A face in frontal view B–C head and pronotum in lateral and dorsal view respectively D–G apex of abdomen in ventral, dorsal, lateral and posterior view respectively H apex of projections of the tenth abdominal tergite in lateral view I posttibiae in dorsal view.

FIGURE 2. Photographs of female
Woznessenskia lianhua
sp. nov.
(paratype, ECNU-5053). A face in front view B–C head and pronotum in lateral and dorsal view respectively D–E end of abdomen in ventral and dorsal view respectively F ovipositor in lateral view.

FIGURE 3. Venations of
Woznessenskia lianhua
sp. nov. A
male left fore wing (holotype, ECNU-4948) B female left fore wing (paratype, ECNU-5053) C the enlarged image of red-bordered area in A, blue-shaded areas representing the areas between R-M and CuA1-CuA2 D the enlarged image of red-bordered area in B, blue-shaded areas representing the areas between R-M and CuA1-CuA2.

FIGURE 4 . Photographs of living
Woznessenskia lianhua
sp. nov.
of male ( A ) and female ( B ).

subSection.paragraph:
The separation or fusion of R-M and CuA1-CuA2 areas was considered as a distinguishing feature between
W . arcoida
and
W . arcuata ( Guo & Shi 2011 )
. However, we observed both instances of separation and fusion between R-M and CuA1-CuA2 areas in
Woznessenskia lianhua
sp. nov.
( Fig. 3 ). We only examined one male and one female specimen and cannot fully confirm whether the differences in wing venation are due to sexual dimorphism or individual variation within this species. In subsequent classification study for this genus, attention should be paid to these veins on fore wings.
